title: Writing email and text messages to users

details.body:
This guide explains how to write emails and text message notifications to users of your service.

If you’re planning to send messages, you also need to think about:

  • using common components (including GOV.UK Notify)
  • [how to protect users from spam and phishingXXXXX]

Meeting the Digital Service Standard

To pass point 13 (make the user experience consistent with GOV.UK) in your service assessments you must use GOV.UK design patterns and guidance.

Read the guide on using, adapting and creating design patterns before you start writing or sending anything.

Plan what you want to say

Before you write anything:

  • make sure you understand what users need to know - only send messages that are timely and relevant
  • work out if an email or text message will more effective - if possible, use both

If you aren’t sure, do user research.

Personalise your message

Users are more likely to trust information that’s clearly directed at them. This means you should:

  • make sure your message is relevant - it might confuse the user if they can’t see how it relates to their situation
  • tailor your message to the user - for example, use ‘visa application’ for the email subject line rather than a reference number or something generic like ‘Application’
  • start emails with ‘Dear [name]’ not ‘Hi’ as some users find it too informal - you don’t need either for text messages
  • say who the message is from - the name of your service might mean more to the user than your department or agency name
  • avoid calling users ‘customers’ - they don’t have a choice about whether to use government services
  • include a reference number (if you have one)

Tell users only what they need to know

It’s easier for users to read and understand messages if they’re short and to the point. When writing a message:

  • start with the most important information - this means the user will be more likely see it, especially if their device or software shortens email subject lines or previews text messages
  • say only one important thing - if you have several important things to say, you might need to send more than one message
  • write just enough so the user will know what to do without needing to contact you for help - don’t explain your service, process or policy

Give clear instructions

Make it easy for users to understand what they need to do and what’s happening next. To do this, you should:

  • include the date and time of any deadlines
  • make it clear what you need the user to do - for example ‘Complete this form and send it back to us by 20 May’
  • say what will happen if they don’t do what you’re asking - for example, ‘If you don’t pay by 20 May, you’ll have to apply for a new licence’
  • tell the user what you’ll do next and when they’ll hear from you - if you won’t be contacting them again, make it clear it’s the end of the process

Spell out links

If your message includes a website link, you should:

  • spell out the web address (URL) in full rather than using a descriptive link, for example https://www.gov.uk/changeaddressdrivinglicence - this helps users know where the link is going
  • avoid link-shortening services as users can’t tell what the URL links to - you’re also dependent on an external provider to keep the link secure

If your text message ends with a URL, don’t use a full stop to end the sentence. This is because it will break the link.

Use plain English

Always write in plain English and follow the Government Digital Service (GDS) style guide.

This means you should:

  • use common words and short sentences - at most 25 words per sentence
  • avoid using jargon or acronyms - if you have to use them, explain what they mean
  • address users as ‘you’ and your service team or department as ‘we’
  • use the active voice - for example, ‘We sent you an email’ not ‘An email was sent to you’

Examples

Use these best practice examples to see how emails and messages should be written:
